images.copyright: View of Edinburgh Castle from a churchyard in Scotland, United Kingdom (© Chris Dorney/Alamy Stock Photo)
images.title: A haunting history
images.caption: Edinburgh Castle, Scotland, United Kingdom
images.desc: Positioned high on an extinct volcano, these fortress walls have seen wars, royal births, executions and plenty of other drama since the 11th century. But what really sets it apart is its reputation as one of Scotland's most haunted spots. It's no surprise that with more than 1,000 years of history, some have reported ghost sightings.

images.copyright: Great horned owl (© Mark Newman/Getty Images)
images.title: Hoots and haunts
images.caption: Great horned owl
images.desc: The Halloween season is upon us, so let's meet one of the holiday's icons: the great horned owl. With its keen vision, eerie vocalisations and silent flight, this owl has historically been revered and feared. In folklore and mythology, owls were considered symbols of wisdom and omens of death. On Samhain, the Celtic precursor to Halloween, the owl was believed to be the kin of roaming spirits.

og.title: Great horned owl
og.desc: The Halloween season is upon us, so let's meet one of the holiday's icons: the great horned owl. With its keen vision, eerie vocalisations…

images.copyright: Pumpkin field, Victoria, British Columbia, Canada (© Shaun Cunningham/Alamy Stock Photo)
images.title: Pumpkins aplenty
images.caption: Pumpkin field, Victoria, British Columbia, Canada
images.desc: Today's image shows a pumpkin field in Victoria in British Columbia, Canada. Five species of pumpkins are commonly cultivated: Cucurbita moschata (pumpkin), Cucurbita pepo (summer squash), Cucurbita maxima (winter squash), Cucurbita mixta (also known as Cucurbita angyrosperma, a type of winter squash) and Cucurbita ficifolia (Malabar gourd or fig-leaf gourd). In general, 'pumpkins' refer to the mature edible fruits of all five Cucurbita species, which are typically not baked.

og.title: Pumpkin field, Victoria, British Columbia, Canada

images.copyright: Polar bear with cub, Churchill, Manitoba, Canada (© Design Pics/plainpicture)
images.title: A mother's warmth in the cold
images.caption: Polar Bear Week
images.desc: Polar Bear Week champions one of nature's greatest hunters, the Arctic's majestic predator. Established by Polar Bears International, this period highlights the challenges these mammals face due to climate change, particularly the rapid loss of Arctic Sea ice. This event coincides with the gathering of polar bears in Churchill, Canada—the 'Polar Bear Capital of the World'—as seen in today's image. Here, bears wait for Hudson Bay to freeze so they can start hunting for seals, their primary food source.
images.bsTitle: A mother's warmth in the cold

images.copyright: Gespensterwald, Nienhagen, Mecklenburg-West Pomerania, Germany (© mauritius images GmbH/Alamy Stock Photo)
images.title: Mysterious woods by the sea
images.caption: Gespensterwald, Nienhagen, Germany
images.desc: In the coastal region of Mecklenburg-West Pomerania in Germany lies the Gespensterwald, which means 'Ghost Forest,' seen in today's image. This spine-tingling forest covers about 1.8 square kilometres, with its gnarled beech, hornbeam, ash and oak trees twisting toward the sky. The salty sea air from the Baltic Sea and the moist climate contribute to the trees' distorted shapes, giving rise to the forest's haunted moniker. Visitors experience light-hearted brushes with the supernatural, such as the crunch of dead leaves, a friendly spirit waving hello from afar or a mischievous ghost peeking from behind a tree. The strategic lighting, which casts ghostly shadows, along with the sculptures and decorations placed along the path, are elements that enhance the forest's ghostly aura throughout the year.

og.title: Gespensterwald, Nienhagen, Germany

images.copyright: Golden Temple at dusk, Amritsar (© Vincent Boisvert, all right reserved/Getty Images)
images.title: A timeless glow
images.caption: Golden Temple, Amritsar
images.copyrightonly: © Vincent Boisvert, all right reserved/Getty Images
images.desc: Glistening like a jewel under the sun, the Golden Temple is not just a place of worship—it's an experience for the soul. A gurudwara in Amritsar, Punjab, it is also known as Sri Darbar Sahib or Sri Harmandir Sahib. The site's journey began in 1577, when Guru Ram Das, the fourth Sikh Guru, completed the man-made pool surrounding the temple. Fast forward to 1604, and it was the fifth Guru, Guru Arjan, who placed the sacred Adi Granth within the temple, shaping its spiritual significance. Despite facing destruction multiple times at the hands of Mughal and Afghan invaders, the Sikhs showed resilience, rebuilding the temple each time.

images.copyright: Bodie State Historic Park, Mono County, California, USA (© Julien McRoberts/Tetra Images, LLC/Alamy Stock Photo)
images.title: Ghosts of the gold rush
images.caption: Bodie State Historic Park, California, United States
images.copyrightonly: © Julien McRoberts/Tetra Images, LLC/Alamy Stock Photo
images.desc: In the ghostly silence of Bodie in California, United States, it feels like time stands still. This once-booming gold rush town was established in 1860. Bodie was named after W.S. Bodey, a prospector who discovered gold but tragically died in a blizzard before seeing the town's rise. When large deposits of gold were found there, it grew to nearly 10,000 residents, with saloons, dance halls and breweries lining its streets. But as the gold ran dry, so did the town's fortunes. The mines closed, the population dwindled and by 1915, the place was abandoned. Bodie's streets are now empty, its wooden buildings frozen in decay.

og.title: Bodie State Historic Park, California, United States

images.copyright: Madame Sherri Forest and the remnant of an old castle, New Hampshire, USA (© yggdrasill/Shutterstock)
images.title: Stairway to nowhere
images.caption: Madame Sherri Forest, New Hampshire, United States
images.desc: Madame Sherri Forest in Chesterfield, New Hampshire, United States, is a captivating destination steeped in history and natural beauty. It was once the site of an extravagant house built in the 1930s by Madame Antoinette Sherri, a flamboyant 1920s costume designer known for her lavish parties. Madame Sherri's dramatic arrivals in town, often in a chauffeur-driven Packard, draped in furs, became the talk of the locals. As her fortune declined, her 'castle' fell into disrepair and was vandalised. In 1959, she returned to find her property in ruins and never came back. A fire destroyed the house in 1963, leaving behind only the stone foundation, an iconic staircase and a large fireplace leading to a lone chimney.
